content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

content:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.   Slides can be added in a few ways:
 Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.  Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: An example talk using Academic's Markdown slides feature.
title: Example Talk

content:
IntroductionIwasaki and Grubaugh (2020) indicates that although Japan has a dense and aging population, it still reported low cases of COVID-19 infection in the first few months of the COVID-19 outbreak, compared with other countries. However, according to the latest COVID-19 report from the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan, Japan has experienced the second outbreak of COVID-19 from July 2020 (Ministry of Health and Welfare (2020)). And it is more serious than the first one. Therefore, this post will focus on the COVID-19 cases of Japan.
Data descriptionFor exploring the COVID-19 situations of Japan, the post has used the COVID-19 data from the package called coronavirus. This package is from the Github repository owned by Rami Krispin, which could find all information related to this package from Github. By glimpsing this data, there are 175055 observations and 7 variables. Based on the help page of the coronavirus package, Krispin and Byrnes (2020) indicate the variables are in the following table 1:
Table 1: Description of variables in coronavirus dataVariableClassDescriptiondateDateThe format of date is YYYY-MM-DDprovincecharacterName of province or state, if providedcountrycharacterName of country or regionlatnumericLatitude of center of geographic regionlongnumericLongitude of center of geographic regiontypecharacterType of cases (confirmed, death, recovered)casesintegerNumber of cases on given dateBecause this post will focus on the cases of Japan, the filter function will be used to filter the data which makes the data only include Japan’s cases. Besides, because the types of COVID-19 cases are all contained in the same column, the function call pivot_wider will be applied to change the position of type as a variable rather than value.
Data story.table.table-striped.table-hover, .table thead th {font-size: 5px;}Table 2: Summary table of COVID-19 cases in Japanyearmonthmonthly confirmedmonthly deathmonthly recoveredcumulative confirmedcumulative deathcumulative recovered202011501150120202230631245632202032010613922255674242020412029414203614284481246020205246741711882167518981434220206186474211618615972164582020717619368316362341008247742020832162290315646839612985633820209151952771918483591157575522202010344839360187039161479123In order to explore the COVID-19 situations of Japan and identify the second outbreak situation, a summary table has been generated to support the following explanation. Table 2 indicates the monthly cases and cumulative cases of Japan from the first patient have been confirmed to the end of August 2020. Based on table 2, there were little cases in the first three month in Japan, which were only 2255 total cases and just account for 3.3% of the total confirmed cases. The first outbreak happened in April of 2020, which reported 12029 cases increased in this month, and the total cases have jumped to 14284 cases. The confirmed cases of April have increased 433.44% compared with the first three month total confirmed cases. Fortunately, the monthly confirmed cases of May and June all gradually decreased, and the total confirmed cases have slowly increased. However, May has reported the highest mortality among the eight months. There were 417 death cases in May, and it even three cases higher than that of the first outbreak, which was 414 cases. The reason might because the outbreak in April resulted in high confirmed cases so that led to the highest mortality in May. But, fortunately, the monthly recovered cases in May was 11882, and the cumulative recovered cases have reached to 14342, which accounted for 85.62% of the cumulative confirmed cases. And the recovery rate of June has reached to 88.41%.
However, because of the gradual return to works or the consciousness of defenses for COVID-19 of people may already be worn down. Japan also experienced the same second COVID-19 outbreak like other countries. The monthly confirmed cases of July have recorded at 17619, which increased 845.23% over June. Furthermore, August has recorded the highest monthly confirmed cases within eight months, which were 32162 cases. Such high monthly cases have contributed to the dramatic increase in cumulative confirmed cases of August which were 68396. And the monthly confirmed rate of August has accounted for almost a half among the total cases in eight months, which was 47.02%. Fortunately, there were only 36 death cases and 290 death cases in July and August, respectively. In addition, the recovered cases in July and August were also high, which were 8316 and 31564 cases, respectively. Finally, there are 82.37% of patients have reported as recovery at the end of August. That should be good news for Japan.
Interactive tableFor helping the readers to better realise the COVID-19 situation of Japan. An interactive table has been created for the readers to explore the data of COVID-19 in Japan. Please refer to the following Figure 1.
{"x":{"url":"/post/COVID_19_JAPAN/COVID-19-Japan_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_DT-table.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 1: The interactive table of COVID-19 situations in JapanConclusionMany countries have experienced the second COVID-19 outbreak nowadays, as well as Japan. Everyone still needs to keep their consciousness of defense this pandemic. Furthermore, hoping the novel coronavirus vaccine will come out as soon as possible, as well as there is no increasing trend of confirmed cases in Japan.
AcknowledgementFor the reproducibility of this post, You can find the relevant information of coronavirus package in this Github repository. In addition, the versions of R and packages which used in this post would be listed in the following.
The programming language used to write the data story of COVID-19 in Japan is R (4.0.2) (R Core Team 2020). Following packages has been included in our scripts:
package coronavirus (0.3.0.9000) (Krispin and Byrnes 2020),package tidyverse (1.3.0) (Wickham et al. 2019),package kableExtra (1.1.0) (Zhu 2019),package tibble (3.0.3) (Müller and Wickham 2020),package lubridate (1.7.9) (Grolemund and Wickham 2011),package widgetframe (0.3.1) (Karambelkar 2017),package DT (0.15) (Xie, Cheng, and Tan 2020),package htmltools (0.5.0) (Cheng et al. 2020)ReferencesCheng, Joe, Carson Sievert, Winston Chang, Yihui Xie, and Jeff Allen. 2020. Htmltools: Tools for Html. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=htmltools.
Grolemund, Garrett, and Hadley Wickham. 2011. “Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate.” Journal of Statistical Software 40 (3): 1–25. http://www.jstatsoft.org/v40/i03/.
Iwasaki, Akiko, and Nathan D Grubaugh. 2020. “Why Does Japan Have so Few Cases of Covid-19?” EMBO Molecular Medicine 12 (5): e12481.
Karambelkar, Bhaskar. 2017. Widgetframe: ’Htmlwidgets’ in Responsive ’Iframes’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=widgetframe.
Krispin, Rami, and Jarrett Byrnes. 2020. Coronavirus: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus Covid-19 (2019-nCoV) Dataset. https://github.com/RamiKrispin/coronavirus.
Ministry of Health, Labour, and Japan Welfare. 2020. “Changes in the Number of Individuals Requiring Hospital Treatment, Critically Ill Individuals, and Newly Reported Cases Etc.” https://www.mhlw.go.jp/content/10900000/000666371.pdf.
Müller, Kirill, and Hadley Wickham. 2020. Tibble: Simple Data Frames. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tibble.
R Core Team. 2020. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org/.
Wickham, Hadley, Mara Averick, Jennifer Bryan, Winston Chang, Lucy D’Agostino McGowan, Romain François, Garrett Grolemund, et al. 2019. “Welcome to the tidyverse.” Journal of Open Source Software 4 (43): 1686. https://doi.org/10.21105/joss.01686.
Xie, Yihui, Joe Cheng, and Xianying Tan. 2020. DT: A Wrapper of the Javascript Library ’Datatables’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=DT.
Zhu, Hao. 2019. KableExtra: Construct Complex Table with ’Kable’ and Pipe Syntax. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=kableExtra.
summary: This post will explore the situation of COVID-19 in Japan
title: COVID-19 situations of Japan

content:
body{text-align: justify}h1 {text-align: left}h2{text-align: left}IntroductionAs mention in the first blog post last two weeks ago, Japan has experienced the second outbreak from July 2020, which would generate some negative influences to the country. But how is the situation of COVID-19 in Japan developing for the past two weeks? Therefore, this post will continue to focus on tracking the cases of COVID-19 in Japan based on the first post. However, the first post only uses the statistical tables to support the analysis, which might not be sufficient and comprehensive. Therefore, this post will create some plots to illustrate the pandemic in Japan to show clearer trends and compare.
This post will focus on the overall situation of COVID-19 in Japan first, to identify the general trends of total confirmed cases, total recovered cases, as well as the total mortality in order to evaluate the current condition. After that, the post will go further to analysis the pandemic trend of each city in Japan, as well as make the comparison in order to filter out the most serious area in Japan.
Data storiesThe overall situation of COVID-19 in JapanFigure 1 shows the trends of the total confirmed, recovered, and death cases of Japan from the first patient has been confirmed to 16/09/2020. It is clear that the total confirmed cases and recovered cases have a similar trend during the period. While, the trend of total death cases is flat, which should be a fortunate condition in this pandemic. The first outbreak happens on 01/04, which has experienced a significant increase from around 5000 confirmed cases to around 15000 cases in a month. After that, the trend changed to be moderate, which seems likely that the pandemic has been controlled. Many patients have recovered since 01/05. The total recovered cases increased dramatically until 01/06, which has recorded around 15000 persons.
However, two months later, Japan has experienced the second outbreak of COVID-19. The trend of total confirmed cases has changed and experienced a rapid rise since 01/07. Until 16/09, the total confirmed cases have recorded over 75000 persons. This increase was more significant and longer than the first one. However, it is clear that the total recovered rate also follows a similar trend of the total confirmed cases in the second outbreak, which might indicate that the medical system and therapy of Japan have sufficient abilities to handle COVID-19, and hospitals could help patients to recover as soon as possible.
Furthermore, Japan has recorded low mortality during the pandemic. By comparing with Figure 2 which shows the daily cases in Japan, the daily death cases were never over 30 people per day, which could show the world-class of the Japanese medical system. Besides, Figure 2 could also help readers easier to evaluate the total confirmed cases and recovery. 11/04 and 30/07 are the two daily confirmed cases peak of two outbreaks, which have recorded 701 and 1762, respectively. Meanwhile, 10/05 was the first peak of daily recovered rate which was 2221 persons, while 15/08 was the second peak which indicated 3941 persons have recovered on that day. Interestingly, 14/08 has recorded a negative daily recovery which was -693. A reason may be the recording mistake required to remove 693 people from the total recovered rate. In addition, since 15/08, the daily recovered cases, in general, higher than the daily confirmed cases, which could indicate the gap between the confirmed cases and recovered cases was reducing, the recovery rate might meet the confirmed rate and the pandemic might disappear.
Figure 1: Total confirmed, recovered, and deadth cases of COVID-19 in Japan (dd/mm)","font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":14.6118721461187}},"hoverformat":".2f"},"yaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"type":"linear","autorange":false,"range":[-924.7,4172.7],"tickmode":"array","ticktext":["0","1000","2000","3000","4000"],"tickvals":[0,1000,2000,3000,4000],"categoryorder":"array","categoryarray":["0","1000","2000","3000","4000"],"nticks":null,"ticks":"outside","tickcolor":"rgba(51,51,51,1)","ticklen":3.65296803652968,"tickwidth":0.66417600664176,"showticklabels":true,"tickfont":{"color":"rgba(77,77,77,1)","family":"","size":11.689497716895},"tickangle":-0,"showline":false,"linecolor":null,"linewidth":0,"showgrid":true,"gridcolor":"rgba(235,235,235,1)","gridwidth":0.66417600664176,"zeroline":false,"anchor":"x","title":{"text":"cases","font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":14.6118721461187}},"hoverformat":".2f"},"shapes":[{"type":"rect","fillcolor":"transparent","line":{"color":"rgba(51,51,51,1)","width":0.66417600664176,"linetype":"solid"},"yref":"paper","xref":"paper","x0":0,"x1":1,"y0":0,"y1":1}],"showlegend":true,"legend":{"bgcolor":"rgba(255,255,255,1)","bordercolor":"transparent","borderwidth":1.88976377952756,"font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":11.689497716895},"y":0.96751968503937,"orientation":"h"},"annotations":[{"text":"type","x":1.02,"y":1,"showarrow":false,"ax":0,"ay":0,"font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":14.6118721461187},"xref":"paper","yref":"paper","textangle":-0,"xanchor":"left","yanchor":"bottom","legendTitle":true}],"hovermode":"closest","barmode":"relative"},"config":{"doubleClick":"reset","showSendToCloud":false},"source":"A","attrs":{"a02c2ea853f3":{"x":{},"y":{},"shape":{},"colour":{},"type":"scatter"},"a02c1d15476f":{"x":{},"y":{},"shape":{},"colour":{}}},"cur_data":"a02c2ea853f3","visdat":{"a02c2ea853f3":["function ","x"]},"highlight":{"on":"plotly_click","persistent":false,"dynamic":false,"selectize":false,"opacityDim":0.2,"selected":{"opacity":1},"debounce":0},"shinyEvents":["plotly_hover","plotly_click","plotly_selected","plotly_relayout","plotly_brushed","plotly_brushing","plotly_clickannotation","plotly_doubleclick","plotly_deselect","plotly_afterplot","plotly_sunburstclick"],"base_url":"https://plot.ly"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 2: Interactive plot of daily confirmed, recovered , and death cases of COVID-19 in Japan (22/01/2020-16/09/2020)COVID-19 situation of cities in JapanAfter evaluating the general situation of COVID-19, further analysing would be conducted in this section. Figure 3 is an interactive table that shows the latest COVID-19 data (15/09/2020) of each city in Japan. The cities on the first page are the top six cities that have the highest confirmed cases. This section would focus on six cities to analyse the condition of COVID-19.
{"x":{"url":"/post/COVID_19_JAPAN_post2/COVID_19_JAPAN_post2_files/figure-html//widgets/widget_find-top-six.html","options":{"xdomain":"*","allowfullscreen":false,"lazyload":false}},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}Figure 3: The latest total cases of confirmed, recovered, and death of each city in Japan (in 15/09/2020)Figure 4 shows the COVID-19 condition of the first six highest confirmed cases of cities in Japan. However, by browsing that plot, and compared with the Figure 1, we found that the figures of Figure 4 since June might not be credible because the trend of all cases never changed, while the total cases have still experienced an increasing trend in Japan. Therefore, the section would only focus on the first outbreak of COVID-19 in Japan, which was the period from January to May.
Tokyo has accounted for the highest total confirmed cases among the six cities, which may be the high dimension of the population in Tokyo city. In addition, Osaka is the city with the second-highest total confirmed cases which were almost 2000 persons. While the rest countries have similar total confirmed cases which were around 1000 persons.
In addition, Osaka, Kanagawa, Hokkaido, Saitama, and Chiba have similar total mortality which was less than 500 persons. Tokyo, however, has the highest mortality because of the highest confirmed cases. Furthermore, Tokyo and Osaka were the two cities with the highest recovery rate which were around 3600 and 1400, respectively. The city of Kanagawa and Saitama has similar recovered cases which were around 1000 persons. While the city of Chiba and Hokkaido have accounted for the least recovery rate which was over 500 persons during the five months.
Figure 4: Total confirmed, recovered, and death cases of COVID-19 of the first six highest confirmed cases cities (15/03/2020-13/09/2020)ConclusionsIn general, Japan has still experienced the increasing trends of confirmed cases. However, the daily recovery rate has overtaken the daily confirmed cases since the middle of August, which might show a piece of positive information because the recovered people were more than the confirmed patients. It might implicate that Japan was experiencing the process of recovery. In addition, Tokyo and Osaka were the most serious cities in the first outbreak of COVID-19. Although the city of Kanagawa, Hokkaido, Saitama, and Chiba also accounted for the first six highest confirmed case, the confirmed, and death cases were low compared with the top two cities.
AcknowledgementThis post has used two datasets for carrying out the analysis. The first one is from coronavirus package, which is used for doing the evaluation of the general trend of COVID-19 in Japan. And the second one is from nCov2019 package, which is used for analysing the COVID-19 condition of cities in Japan. Click the link and you can get more details from the websites.
The programming language used to write the data stories of COVID-19 in Japan is R (4.0.2) (R Core Team 2020). Following packages has been included in the scripts:
package tidyverse (1.3.0) (Wickham et al. 2019),package ggplot2 (3.3.2) (Wickham 2016),package dplyr (1.0.1) (Wickham et al. 2020),package plotly (4.9.2.1) (Sievert 2020),package lubridate (1.7.9) (Grolemund and Wickham 2011),package DT (0.15) (Xie, Cheng, and Tan 2020),package widgetframe (0.3.1) (Karambelkar 2017),package htmltools (0.5.0) (Cheng et al. 2020),package coronavirus (0.3.0) (Krispin and Byrnes 2020),package nCov2019 (0.3.6) (Yu 2020)ReferencesCheng, Joe, Carson Sievert, Winston Chang, Yihui Xie, and Jeff Allen. 2020. content:
body{text-align: justify}h1 {text-align: left}h2{text-align: left}An overview of the packageThis post is used to execute the peer review of another R package called covideu which created by the author of Joyce Lee. According to the README and vignette files, the purpose of the package is providing the dataset used in the shiny app, as well as the coding processes within the app.R of the shiny app. Therefore, the shiny app of COVID-19 in EU has been decomposed and becomes several elements in the package. There are four functions and four package data in the package. The package data are eutable_draft, owid, owid_eu and owid_eu_long, respectively. While those four functions included draw_plot(), launch_app(), ic() and select1country(). Meanwhile, the package also contains the vignette which introduces how to use the function to run the app, as well as the introduction and guidelines of the app. Besides, there is a pkgdown website of the package which includes the documentation for the package, like the instructions and overview of the package, the documentation of the functions and package data, and the vignette site. Furthermore, the documentation of the functions and data could be found on the help page.
Assumption about this packageBy reading through the contents in the pkgdown website, I supposed this package could allow me to explore the data which used in the app, as well as provide me with the functions which are similar the coding processes in the app. Meanwhile, the documentation of data and functions also led me to assume that the package data would provide coronavirus information of the European Union and the world, while the functions of the package would help launch the app, generate a plot and the tag of country, as well as select a country.By trying the provided commands in the package, I found that the command of generating that four package data could run successfully, and the results are as expected. In addition, the launch_app function also meets my expectation which is running the app successfully. Meanwhile, the function of ic() generates the format of the tag$style(HTML()) for the targeted country, which is also as expected.
Another two functions, however, might not satisfy my assumption. Even though the function of draw_plot() could create the plot successfully. The bar chart just shows two pillars of the same height without suitable values of both y-axis and x-axis. Because I assumed that it would be a time-series plot which displays the daily cases of the inputted country, meanwhile, the x-axis would show the date and the y-axis would show the value of cases. But the fact that the result is not what I expected. Besides, I suppose that the select1country function would allow users to select one country and return the relevant information of that country. However, because of the lack of particular documentation of this function, I cannot run this function successful. By checking the code in the R file, I found that the author creates a UI of shiny in this function. Indeed, this function generates a selection bar and be shown on the page of README.md. However, this is not I expected.
ImprovementsImprovements for the codeOverall, the author did well in the coding part. However, two parts could be improved. The first one is in the r2.R file which is the R file of draw_plot function. Based on the documentation and return (the return I got is only two pillars when I inputted one country name and I cannot input multiple names) of that function, I think the argument x should be an inputted element to select one country that a user wants to observe. Therefore, there should be a step before ggplot2::ggplot() to filter out the country rather than putting the country name as the x-axis. Because the argument of x has been used to filter the country, we need a new element to be as the x-axis. By checking the dataset of owid_eu_long (the suggested data in the documentation), I will suggest that put the variable of date as the x-axis, which could help to create a plot to display the daily cases by date. Besides, make the argument of fill as an optional argument which could not only allow users to create the daily-cases plot but also allow users to plot the total confirmed cases and total death cases. This could achieve by setting fill = "" or fill = NULL in function(). At the same time, the documentation of the draw_plot function should be updated to increase the descriptions of the arguments.
Another improvement that is suggested is because of my personal preference which is trying to break the long-line argument input into several short lines. For example, in the owid_eu.R file, the author wanted to select the countries in the EU (on line 5). However, the author put all the name of countries in one line, which might be hard for users to read the whole code. Actually, the author could try to break it into several short lines, that is putting each name of the country in one line. The author could also try to do the same thing on line 6.
Improvements for the shiny appThe author did well in the shiny app. However, there are several points I considered could be improved. Firstly, the colour of the tags of About and Main is similar to the background colour, try to change the colour which could highlight these two tags. Secondly, try to clear the instructions of how to use the sidebar panel in the shiny app, put more details in the guidelines would help users easier to use. Besides, the author could describe the outputs in more details. Thirdly, try to add the selected date in the title, which might make it clearer. The last one is removing the sidebar panel in the About section because it is unnecessary in that section.
Improvements for the documentationsIn my opinion, the documentation of data is good. But adding the description of the variables within each dataset in the documentation would be better. The documentation of functions, however, are not sufficient enough for me to get started, except for the documentation of the launch_app(). Trying to explain the return of each function might guide the expectation of users for results and provide a better understanding to users for the results. Meanwhile, the author also needs to provide the examples of each function, which could help users to understand how to use the function, as well as the arguments. At last, try to provide more details in the part of the argument of documentations to tell users the required element and format of each argument in the function.
The things I have learned from the reviewingIn my opinion, by reviewing another R package could help me realise some parts I missed or did not do well in my package. For example, I found that I forgot to put the R CMD check status link to into the README file, therefore, the check result would not show on the README.md in Github. Also, the peer review helps me to learn something new or gain some new ideas from others. By checking the shiny app, I found that users could slide the plot to the left or right to control the number of objects shown in the plot. That would be a convenient way to compare the different number of objects without further specify the number of objects. And I might use this method in my future works. Furthermore, reviewing the package could also help me realise the important elements in the documentation of the package. Like the parts of arguments, value and examples, or the description of variables in the data. These elements could all help users understand the function or data in the package, as well as a guild the user to utilise them. In conclusion, peer review is a helpful process for both authors or reviews, it could help each other to realise the mistakes and learn some new ideas.
AcknowledgementThe repository of this package could be found in this Github link. Or you could use the command devtools::install_github(“etc5523-2020/r-package-assessment-jlee0179”) to install the package if you want to investigate it.
AppendixPackage ReviewPlease check off boxes as applicable, and elaborate in comments below.
DocumentationThe package includes all the following forms of documentation:
Installation instructions: for the package is found in README
Comment: Author clearly explains how to install the package and provides the relevant code
Vignette(s) demonstrating major functionality that runs successfully locally
Comment: The vignette could be run successfully locally, and the vignette demonstrates the documentation of the major functionality and the package data.
Function Documentation: for all exported functions in R help
Comment: The function documentation of all exported functions and data could be found in the R help page. However, in my opinion, some of the documentation is insufficient to guide users to use the function.
Examples for all exported functions in R Help that run successfully locally
Comment: Cannot find any examples in the R help page of all exported function and package data.
FunctionalityInstallation: Installation succeeds as documented.
Comment: Following the instruction of installation, I can install the package successfully.
Functionality: Any functional claims of the software been confirmed.
Comment: Not all the functional claims of the software could be confirmed. Because some of the documentation of functionality are inadequate. Thus, some of the functions are unclear to how to use and this might be a reason that cannot confirm the claims. But the function of select1country() cannot help to select one country in R studio. In addition, the function of draw_plot() only return same height bar plot instead of the plot of the daily case. The function of ic() also cannot return what it describes as. However, in the README, the select1country() generate a selection bar and indeed enable the selection of a country. While the ic() function also indeed returns the format of tag$style(HTML()). Besides, the rest of the functional claims could be confirmed.
Automated tests: Unit tests cover essential functions of the package and a reasonable range of inputs and conditions. All tests pass on the local machine.
Comment: There are no unit tests included in the package.
summary: This post is used to review the R package of another classmate to provide some useful suggestions and highlight some points I am interested.
title: The Peer Review of Another R Package

content:
body{text-align: justify}h1 {text-align: left}h2{text-align: left}Introduction and motivationThe first two posts have introduced the basic information of COVID-19 in Japan. Because the analytic directions of the posts were subjective, the figures and tables are determined and constant, which means they are generated based on the directions of the analysis. This type of table and figure might reduce the engagement of readers and cannot provide sufficient access for readers to further exploring the data. Therefore, a Shiny app of COVID-19 has been created to provide opportunities for readers to explore the situation of COVID-19 in their interested countries.
There are three countries available in the app currently, which are Japan, Australia, and the US. Meanwhile, the Shiny app contains three main sections. The first section is about, which introduces the basic information, like author and student ID, and the purpose of the app. The second section is app, which contains three subsections of explanation, figure, and table. The subsection of explanation provides an overview of the structure of the app, which might help users understand the functions of each section and get familiar with the app. Meanwhile, it provides the instructions of subsections of figure and table. The subsections of figure and table provide the chances for users to explore the information of COVID-19. Users could select the elements they are interested in, and the corresponding figures or tables would be generated based on the selections of users.
In the subsection of figure, users could select the country, the scope of months, or a specific month they want to observe. The top figure would display the total trend of a selected country in the selected months. Three lines would be shown in the figure, which represents the total confirmed cases, total death, and total recovered cases, respectively. The default range of months would be from January to October 2020. While the bottom figure shows the fluctuation of those three cases within a month. In the subsection of table, users could create a table by selecting a country and the frequency of the cases, which is monthly or daily. In addition, users could decide the level of the data, which means users could choose country-based or province-based data for creating the table.
The last section of citation lists the data source, packages, and references used in the Shiny app, which provide the chance of reproducibility for users who want to reproduce or update the app.
Self ReviewThe good points of the appFirstly, the paragraphs of structure in the subsection of explanation should not be seen as wordy because it provides users a better understand of components of the app and help them get familiar with the app.
Secondly, the app provides multiple choices for users to further explore the situation of COVID-19. The subsection of figure allows users to select either a range of months or a specific month, which not only helps users gain an overview of the general trend of COVID-19 but also provides a chance to users to investigate the situation within a specific month. Meanwhile, users could choose a month by clicking the point in the general trend figure directly, which would be more convenient. In the subsection of table, the app allows users to observe either the cases of a country or a province in the frequency of monthly or daily, which would help users analyse COVID-19 comprehensively. Meanwhile, users could filter or search the information in the table.
Besides, the format of the app is unified. In the interactive subsection, all the selection bars are placed on the left side of the page, while the respondent figures or table are placed on the right-hand side. Besides, the format of that two figures is also consistent, like the same title size, and the same colour of the types of COVID-19 cases in both figures.
Furthermore, the title and the explanation of each figure or table could be altered automatically based on the choices of users. That could be helpful for users to understand the contents of each figure and table by the title and the explanations because the title and explanations are consistent with the choices of users.
At last, there are two buttons below each figure and table, which are guide and output. The guide button shows the steps of creating the corresponding figure or table, which would be helpful for users to create the figure or table easily. While the output button explains the components of the figures and table, as well as their contents.
The points that need improvementsFirstly, a picture showing the structure of the app would be inserted in the subsection of explanation to improve the illustration, rather than the literal statements only. Secondly, the size of characters in the selection bars could be increased to make them clearer. Thirdly, the in-text citations should be added in any explanation parts to help users gain associations with the supporting materials, included referencing the figure, table, section, and the data source.
While, an important point that needs to be improved is the illustration of each diagram and table, as what is available is inadequate. A paragraph explaining the trends and variations in the chart and the contents of the table should be added, which would help to explain the outputs of the figures and table.
At last, the original dataset of this app should be enlarged, which should contain more data from countries.
Some things that would like to addBecause the subsection of figure is used to display the trend of COVID-19 by diagrams. By considering how to inspire users to select a country or provide users a more intuitive sense of the general situation, a map of the world should be placed on the sidebar panel. This map would show the level of confirmed cases by colours and highlight the included countries of the dataset only. Meanwhile, the map would be a click plotly and users could choose a country by clicking the country on the map directly.
Besides, the subsection of table provides a chance for users to investigate the situation of a province in a country. A map of the country would be added in the sidebar panel to show the total confirmed cases of each province in a country by colours, which would also provide an intuitive sense of the COVID-19 situation. The map would popup when users select province-based data, and users could click a province in the map to get the corresponding table.
The limitations that prevent from adding new thingsAlthough some new things are discussed, they did not be added to the app yet due to the limitation in data. Firstly, the original dataset is incomplete. Some data of provinces are missing in the dataset, and not all countries have provincial data. Secondly, the limitation of latitude and longitude of all provinces would also make the map of a country absent. Besides, adding the in-text citations in the Shiny app is not finished yet due to limitations of the technology of the creator, and it would be solved later.
AcknowledgementThis Shiny app has been published in the service of ShinyApps.io, you could check the app here. (The app might be sleeping because of the limitation of active time of the free account, therefore you might not run the app.)
The programming language used to write the self reflection is R (4.0.2) (R Core Team 2020)..
ReferencesR Core Team. 2020. R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing. Vienna, Austria: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. https://www.R-project.org/.
summary: This post is a self reflection which used to improve the Shiny app of COVID-19 situation exploration.
title: The Self-reflection of Shiny App

.reveal section h1, .reveal section h2, .reveal section h3 { color: navy; }   Questions?  Ask

content:
COVID-19 situations of Japan This post is used for exploring the situations of COVID-19 in Japan.
Data source The data come from the coronavirus package in Github of Rami Krispin. You can browse the related information of coronavirus package by this link.
You have two ways to download the coronavirus package.
CRAN version Try the command:
install.packages(“coronavirus”)
Github version Try the command:
install.packages(“devtools”)
devtools::install_github(“RamiKrispin/coronavirus”)
P.S. You need to install the devtools package first, if you already have this package, please ignore it.
Data refresh To refresh the data, please try:
library(coronavirus)
update_dataset()
Or you can use the Covid19R project data standard format to pull the data, please try:
new_object <- refresh_coronavirus_jhu()
P.S. You can rename the new_object
